question: There's meant to be lace in the next village - the boys are taking me.
answer: I'm not sewing anything else.

question: You don't have any money, do you? Just in case there's silk.
answer: No!

question: Hana, I know you do!
answer: I'm not sewing anything else for you!

question: Do you need something? We keep moving him - in and out of the truck. Why? He's dying. What's the point? I must be a curse. Anybody who loves me, anybody who gets close to me - or I must be cursed. Which is it? The war's over - you told me yourself. How can it be desertion?
answer: It's not over everywhere. I didn't mean literally.

question: When he dies I'll catch up.
answer: It's not safe here. The whole country's crawling with Bandits and Germans and God knows what. It's madness. I can't allow it. You're not, this is natural - it's shock. For all of us. Hana -

question: I need morphine. A lot. And a pistol.
answer: And what if he really is a spy?

question: He can't even move.
answer: If anything happened to you I'd never forgive myself. We're heading for Leghorn. Livorno the Italians call it. We'll expect you.

question: Thirsty?
answer: What's this?

question: Don't drink it! I can't guarantee the vintage, my friends. I just dug it out of the hill.
answer: Excellent. That's terrific, D'Ag. Toss that up, would you.

question: There are some others.
answer: My God, look at this!

question: I've never seen anything like it. There would have been enough water here to serve an army. Why? A pottery hill!
answer: No. No. Now we look in the other places. We're eliminating. Good, and here comes reinforcements.

question: No. No. Now we look in the other places. We're eliminating. Good, and here comes reinforcements.
answer: I hereby Christen us the International Sand Club!

question: Marvelous plane. Did you look?
answer: Isn't it? Wedding present from Katharine's parents. I'm calling it Rupert Bear. Hello. Geoffrey Clifton.

question: What was all the banging? Were you fighting rats or the entire German army?
answer: I was repairing the stairs. I found a library and the books were very useful.

question: Before you find too many uses for these books would you read some to me?
answer: I think they're all in Italian, but I'll look, yes. What about your own book?

question: My book? The Herodotus? Yes, we can read him.
answer: Oh - I've found plums. We have plums in the orchard. We have an orchard!

question: Thank you. The plumness of this plum. What's that?
answer: Water! You hear it, too, don't you!

question: I will hide you in the room where we sleep, said Candaules.
answer: Candaules

question: Candaules...you're laughing at me.
answer: I'm not laughing at you. Go on, please.

question: I should try and move your bed. I want you to be able to see the view. It's good, it's a view from a monastery.
answer: I can already see.

question: How? How can you see anything?
answer: Not the window - I can't bear the light anyway - no, I can see all the way to the desert. I've found the lost fossils.

question: I'm turning you.
answer: Zerzura, the White City of Acacias, the Oasis of Little Birds. As me about the scent of acacia - it's in this room. I can smell it. The taste of tea so black it falls into your mouth. I can taste it. I'm chewing the mint. Is there sand in my eyes? Are you cleaning sand from my ears?

question: No sand. That's your drugs speaking.
answer: I can see my wife in that view.

question: Are you remembering more?
answer: Could I have a cigarette?

question: Are you crazy?
answer: Why are you so determined to keep me alive?

question: Because I'm a nurse. How are you?
answer: Okay.

question: Your leg will be fine. A lot of shrapnel came out - I saved you the pieces.
answer: You're the prettiest girl I ever saw. Would you kiss me?

question: No, I'll get you some tea. Wait till you're in Naples. You'll find a girl there.
answer: Just kiss me. It would mean such a lot to me.

question: Would it?
answer: Thank you.

question: Very funny. Go to sleep. Where are we going? I don't want to be kissing in a crowd. I have six hours.
answer: Whoa - give me a chance!

question: Sorry. I took a Benzedrine.
answer: I've got a surprise. A boat! We can go to Capri. It's got a cabin, it's private.

question: I'd like to spend a night with you in a bed.
answer: We can do that when we're very very old.

question: Buon' Giorno! Are you Hana?
answer: What do you want?

question: I met your friend Mary. She said I should stop and see if you were okay. Apparently we're neighbors - my house is two blocks from yours in Montreal. Cabot, north of Laurier. Bonjour.
answer: Bonjour.

question: I'd like to take credit, but it's from Mary. My name's David Caravaggio, but nobody ever called me David. Caravaggio they find to absurd to miss out on. They're fresh. I haven't eaten an egg in...have you noticed there are chickens? You get chickens in Italy but no eggs. In Africa there were always eggs, but never chickens. Who separates them?
answer: You were in Africa?

question: Yeah, for a while.
answer: So was my Patient.

question: I'd like to stay. That's the long and short of it. I mean, you know blah-blah if it's convenient, if there's room blah-blah-blah. I have to do some work here -I speak the language. There are Partisans to be - #NAME? relieve them of their weapons, you know - while we hug. I was a thief, so they think I'd be good at that.
answer: So you can shoot a pistol?

question: No.
answer: If you said yes I would have had a reason. You should let me redress those bandages. Before you go.

question: I'm okay. Look, it's a big house. We needn't disturb each other. I can shoot a pistol! I'll sleep in the stables. I don't care where I sleep. I don't sleep.
answer: Because we're fine here. I don't know what Mary told you about me, but I don't need company, I don't need to be looked at.

question: Fine. I'm not looking.
answer: There's a man downstairs. He brought us eggs. He might stay.

question: There's a man downstairs. He brought us eggs. He might stay.
answer: Why? Can he lay eggs?

question: He's Canadian.
answer: Why are people always so happy when they collide with someone from the same place? What happened in Montreal when you passed a man in the street - did you invite him to live with you?

question: He needn't disturb you.
answer: Me? He can't. I'm already disturbed.

question: Hello.
answer: Finally! So you're our Canadian pickpocket?

question: Thief, I think, is more accurate.
answer: I understand you were in Africa. Whereabouts?

question: Oh, all over.
answer: All over? I kept trying to cover a very modest portion and still failed. Are you leaving us? Now's our opportunity to swap war wounds.

question: Does she have war wounds?
answer: I think anybody she ever loves tends to die on her.

question: Are you planning to be the exception?
answer: Me? You've got the wrong end of the stick, old boy. So - Caravaggio - Hana thinks you invented your name.

question: And you've forgotten yours.
answer: I told her you would never invent such a preposterous name.

question: Do you remember where you were born?
answer: Am I being interrogated? You should be trying to trick me. Ask me about Tottenham Hotspur. Or Buckingham Palace. About Marmite - I was addicted. Or make me speak German, which I can, by the way.

question: Why? Are you German?
answer: No.

question: How do you know you're not German if you don't remember anything?
answer: You tell me. I remember a lot of things. I remember a garden, plunging down to the sea - the Devil's Chimney we called it - and there was a cottage at the bottom, right on the shore, nothing between you and France.

question: This was your garden?
answer: Or my wife's.

question: Then you were married?
answer: I think so. Although I believe that to be true of a number of Germans. Might I have a glass of water? Thank you. Look - my lungs are useless - I've got this much lung...the rest of my organs are packing up - what could it possibly matter if I were Tutankhamun? I'm a bit of toast, my friend - butter me and slip a poached egg on top.

question: Excuse me -
answer: Yes?

question: Can I ask - my friend, can he come in? Just for a few minutes?
answer: Your friend?

question: He's going back to the front this evening. I can't see him otherwise.
answer: Just go off. I'll be quite all right.

question: No, I can't go, but if it, if you weren't offended, it would be very good of you to allow us - every other cabin is crammed. This is as private as we'll get.
answer: Well then - yes. Of course.

question: Thank you. Thank you. This is Captain McGann.
answer: Please, don't waste your time on pleasantries -

question: You've got a mustache.
answer: A bit of one.

question: I was looking forward to this evening.
answer: I had a hotel room.

question: I thought that was for when we were very very old?
answer: I'm feeling old.

question: Supper.
answer: Where've you been?

question: Rabbit hunting.
answer: I could help you. I could get you off that.

question: Can you cook the rabbit or will you try and bring that back to life?
answer: It's a week. We didn't know where you were - or if you coming back, or -

question: You should be happy. What were you going to do for him when it ran out?
answer: What do you do? What are you doing here?

question: Something smells so rich. My stomach is heaving -
answer: He came back, he says he caught a rabbit. I'm cooking it.

question: That's a different dress.
answer: He keeps asking me questions about you. Do you know him? Do you recognize him?

question: Gentlemen, to Zerzura.
answer: And a special thank you to Geoffrey and Katharine, without whose fund-raising heroics we should still be kicking our heels.

question: To arm-twisting.
answer: Did Katharine say? - Geoffrey has to fly back to Cairo.

question: Portraits. The Brigadier, the Brigadier's wife, the Brigadier's dogs, the Brigadier at the Pyramids, the Brigadier breathing.
answer: Why do you think? About my staying?

question: Well look, if nobody minds, truly, then I suppose - I shall, of course, be bereft...
answer: Oh.

question: But finally able to explore the Cairo night-life. I shall produce an authoritative guide to the Zinc Bars and - I want to say Harems - am I in the right country for Harems? You too. Good luck! Appropriate? Are you mad? Katharine loves it here. She told me yesterday. I've known Katharine since she was three, my aunt is her aunt, we were practically brother and sister before we were man and wife. I think I'd know what is and what isn't too much for her. I think she's know herself. Why are you people so threatened by a woman?!
answer: I've been thinking about - how does somebody like you decide to come to the desert? What is it? You're doing whatever you're doing - in your castle, or wherever it is you live, and one day, you say, I have to go to the desert - or what? Actually, you sing. You sing. All the time. Ask Al Auf. I'll be down to get you in the taxi, honey, you'd better be ready about half-past eight...!

question: I insist. There clearly isn't room for us all, I'm the least able to dig, and I'm not one of the walking wounded. Those are facts. Besides, if I remain it's the most effective method of persuading my husband to abandon whatever he's doing and rescue us. I thought you might paste them into your book. I'd like you to have them. And that would be unconscionable, I suppose, to feel any obligation? Yes. Of course it would. I'm quite all right, thank you. What am I looking at? They're so untidy. I'm just trying to rearrange them. This is not very good, is it? Shall we be all right? Yes is a comfort. Absolutely is not. Fiction. We had a house on that coast and it never rained blood. Go on. More. Our tracks, where are they? Oh my God, the others! Of course. Is it, am I a terrible coward to ask how much water we have? Find that plant. Cut out its heart. Geoffrey's not in Cairo. He's not actually a buffoon. And the plane wasn't a wedding present. It belongs to the British Government. They want aerial maps of the whole North Africa. So I think he's in Ethiopia. In case you were counting on his sudden appearance. No, the marriage isn't a fiction. Thank God. Oh, thank God. Do they know them? Am I K. in your book? I think I must be.
answer: I recollect your saying to ignore your bones but I assume you have no objection to my rescuing your companion? Good evening, Mrs. Clifton.

question: Hello.
answer: I'd like to introduce you to my camel - the most notable beast on earth. I understand you found some remarkable caves. Paintings of swimmers? Remarkable.

question: As him what company he's with?
answer: Third Canadian Fusiliers.

question: Does he know a Captain McGann? What did he say?
answer: Doesn't know him.

question: He's gone, hasn't he?
answer: No. He's - no.

question: Oh God. Oh God.
answer: Hana? Hana? Are you alright?

question: Don't touch me if you're going to try and fuck me.
answer: I'll have some of your water. It's hot. You have to protect yourself from sadness. This is the thing I've learned. You're in love with him, aren't you? Your patient. Do you think he's a saint or something? Because of the way he looks? I don't think he is.

question: I'm not in love with him. I'm in love with ghosts. And so is he. He's in love with ghosts.
answer: Who are his ghosts?

question: Ask him.
answer: What if I told you he did this to me?

question: What? How could he have? When?
answer: I'm one of his ghosts and he wouldn't even know. It's like he slammed a door in Cairo and it trapped my fucking hands in Tobruk.

question: I don't know what that means.
answer: Ask him. Ask your saint who he is. Ask him who he's killed.

question: What? No! No. Coming. I can't sleep. I woke up shouting in the middle of the night. Geoffrey thinks it's the thing in the desert, the trauma. This is empty, just coming! I'm fine. How silly. I don't think so. I think I might go inside and sit down for a few minutes. No, please. I shall be absolutely fine.
answer: Have you seen Katharine? It's Geoffrey under this. Darling, I just heard. You poor sausage, are you all right?

question: I'm fine. I got hot.
answer: Lady H said she thought you might be -

question: I'm not pregnant. I'm hot. I'm too hot.
answer: Right.

question: Aren't you?
answer: Sweltering. Come on, I'll take you home.

question: Can't we really go home? I can't breathe. Aren't you dying for green, anything green, or rain, wouldn't you die to feel rain on your face? It's Christmas and it's all - I don't know - if you asked me I'd go home tomorrow. If you wanted.
answer: Sweetheart, you know we can't go home, there might be a war.

question: Geoffrey, you do so love putting on a disguise.
answer: I do so love you. What do you smell of?

question: What?
answer: Marzipan! I think you've got marzipan in your hair. No wonder you're homesick.

question: Are you outside?
answer: I can't hide anymore. I breathe like a dog. I lose my balance. Stealing's got harder. Why do I feel if I had your book I would know everything?

question: I don't even know if it is my book. The Bedouin found it in the plane, in the wreckage. It's mine now. I heard your breathing and thought it might be rain. I'm dying for rain - of course I'm dying anyway - but I long to feel rain on my face.
answer: Is it you? If I said Moose... I look different, fuck, why shouldn't you?

question: Moose.
answer: First wedding anniversary - what do you call it?

question: Excuse me. Yes? I don't have the key to that door.
answer: The Germans were here. The Germans were all over this area. They left mines everywhere. Pianos were their favorite hiding places.

question: I see. Then may be you're safe as long as you only play Bach. He's German.
answer: Is something funny?

question: No, but, no, not at all. I'm sorry. You came to the doors, that's all and - #NAME? worried about mines. That's all.
answer: I've met you before.

question: I don't think so. He wants us to move out, says there could be fifty more mines in the building. He thinks I'm mad because I laughed at him. He's Indian, he wears a turban.
answer: Sikh. If he wears a turban, he's a Sikh.

question: I'll probably marry him.
answer: Really? That's sudden.

question: My mother always told me I would summon my husband by playing the piano. I liked it better when there were just the two of us.
answer: Why? Is he staying?

question: With his Sergeant. A Mr. Hardy.
answer: We should charge! Doesn't anyone have a job to do?

question: They have to clear all the local roads of mines. That's a big job. They won't stay in the house. They're putting up their tent in the garden.
answer: In that case, I suppose we can't charge.

question: Darling, it's me, I'm sorry, something's come up. Don't sulk - I'll be back tomorrow evening. I promise. Okay my precious, I love you. I'm not. I'm going to surprise her. It's our anniversary. She's forgotten, of course. What's the symbol for your first anniversary? I should get something. Is it paper? Moose! Moose, you there? First Anniversary - is it cotton?
answer: Is what cotton?

question: First Wedding Anniversary. Your day will come, my sausage.
answer: Your first anniversary is Paper.

question: No-one should own music. The real question is who wrote the song?
answer: Irving Berlin.

question: For?
answer: Top Hat.

question: Kip's another one. Hello.
answer: Hello miss.

question: I was going to say - if you want to eat with us, ever... you and Lieutenant Singh...
answer: Very kind of you, we can always eat in the town with the others -

question: Since Caravaggio turned up - food seems to appear, so please.
answer: I'll ask the Lieutenant. But thank you.

question: You saved my life. I haven't forgotten. I thought you were very very tall. You seemed to big - a Giant - and I felt like a child who can't keep her balance.
answer: A toddler

question: Brick platform opposite the old Ajaib-Gher -
answer: #NAME? natives called the Lahore Museum.

question: It's still there, the cannon, outside the museum. It was made of metal cups and bowls taken from every household in the city as tax, then melted down. Then later they fired the cannon at my people - comma - The natives.
answer: So what do you really object to - the writer or what he's writing about?

question: What I really object to, Uncle, is your finishing all my condensed milk. And the message everywhere in your book - however slowly I read it - that the best destiny for India is to be ruled by the British.
answer: Hana, we have discovered a shared please - the boy and I.

question: I didn't like that book either. It's all about men. Too many men. Just like this house.
answer: You like him, don't you? Your voice changes.

question: I don't think it does. Anyway, he's indifferent to me.
answer: I don't think it's indifference. Hana was just telling me that you were indifferent -

question: Hey! -
answer: #NAME?

question: Go to the left! Keep to the left! There are mines and trip wires everywhere! Get Hardy. He's on the other side of town. In the hills. Get him to hurry.
answer: It's okay - I'll help. Please.

question: The mines, the wires, there's a trick. Some explode if you stretch the wires, some if you cut them.
answer: What do I do?

question: There's a mine here, but the others are far enough away, I think at least to give me a chance. I have to work out which one to cut before I fall over.
answer: So I follow the wires?

question: You get Hardy.
answer: I follow the wires.

question: Don't touch them.
answer: Why would anyone do this?

question: I've done this. I've had to do this.
answer: Give me a second.

question: What are you doing?! Hana! What is this business with you and explosives? Do you think you're immune?
answer: I promise you that was the right thing to do. He's my good luck. Now cut. This one. I hope we don't die.

question: Okay. Get away from here. Quick.
answer: I'm not scared. So many people have died around me. But I would be a shame for us. I don't feel like being shy.

question: You must get away. Before I cut. I'm not cutting if you're here.
answer: Actually, you can't cut, can you? You'll fall over. Give me the pliers.

question: No.
answer: Kiss me. Before I cut. Just in case.

question: I'm sorry. I forgot you'd be worrying. We're all safe. It was a mine, but not the mine. Nobody's hurt. I'm sorry.
answer: And you're definitely traveling with him of your own free will?

question: Yes.
answer: Just wanting to be sure. And he's taking you to church?

question: Hold the ends.
answer: What a bloody flap, eh? I heard from Alexandria this morning - apparently no-one there is accepting British pounds. And if you pick up a telephone everybody's practicing their German. What do you do - do you take these things? Look, Moose, we need you to stay in Tobruk. A bit of a short straw but the thinking is we'll be back - I mean, we will be back - but...and in the interim we need eyes and ears on the ground.

question: We have 30, 000 troops in Tobruk. What are they going to be doing?
answer: Giving Rommel a bloody nose. That's my suggestion. But did you hear the BBC last nigh? Tobruk is of no strategic importance - makes you wonder. Jerry's got our maps you know. Swines. Before the war we helped them run about the desert making maps - and now they get spies into Cairo using our maps, they'll get Rommel into Cairo using our maps. The whole of the desert like a bus route and we gave it to them. Any foreigner who turned up - welcome to the Royal Geographic, take our maps. Madox went mad, you know - you knew Peter Madox? - after he found out he'd been betrayed by his friend. Absolutely destroyed the poor sod. Shot himself in a church in Dorset. I'd like to get that bastard Almsy - settle the score, eh? That's my fantasy - said he, clearing out. Must have been a spy all along.

question: Would you like me to? Kip.
answer: I was looking for the Lieutenant Singh.

question: He's sleeping.
answer: Only we have to go to work.

question: I'll tell him. What is it? Is it a mine?
answer: A bomb. At the Viaduct.

question: Does he have to go?
answer: Pardon me?

question: What is this - a bloody carnival? Stop them! You've got to cut, sir, that frost won't last.
answer: Go away.

question: Yessir.
answer: This is making me incredibly angry. Kiss me.

question: Should have been me. It was my idea but Sergeant Hardy climbed up, sir, him and Blackler.
answer: Who's that girl?

question: His fiancee, sir.
answer: Hardy's?

question: Kept it a bit dark.
answer: I was thinking yesterday - yesterday! - the Patient, Hardy

question: I was thinking yesterday - yesterday! - the Patient, Hardy
answer: You loved him. If one night I didn't come to the tent, what would you do?

question: I try not to expect you.
answer: But if it got late and I hadn't shown up?

question: Then I'd think there must be a reason.
answer: You wouldn't come to find me? That makes me never want to come here. Then I tell myself he spends all day searching, in the night he wants to be found.

question: Hana tells me you're leaving.
answer: There are going to be trials, they want me to interpret, don't they know I'm allergic to courtrooms?

question: We shall miss you.
answer: So, I come across the Hospital Convoy I was looking for this stuff, and some nurse, Mary, Hana's friend, tells me about you and Hana, hiding in a monastery, in purdah, whatever it is - retreat - how you'd come in from the Desert and you were burned and you didn't know your name but you knew the words to every song there was and you had one possession - #NAME? full of letters and cuttings, and then I knew it must be you.

question: Me?
answer: I'd seen you writing in that book. At the Embassy in Cairo, when I had thumbs and you had a face. And a name.

question: I see.
answer: Before you went over to the Germans, before you got Rommel's spy across the desert and inside British headquarters. He took some pretty good photographs - I saw mine in that torture room in Tobruk, so they made an impression.

question: And you thought you'd come and settle the score?
answer: You were the only man who knew the desert well enough, the only man who would cross seventeen hundred miles of nothing.

question: I had to get back to the desert. I made a promise. The rest meant nothing to me.
answer: What did you say?

question: The rest meant nothing to me.
answer: There was a result to what you did. It wasn't just another expedition. It did this. If the British hadn't unearthed your nosey photographer in Cairo thousands of people could have died.

question: Thousands of people did die, just different people.
answer: But you were among the British, they were your friends - why betray them?

question: What are you up to?
answer: That gun at Lahor, Kipling's cannon - Zamzammah - remember? That was made out of the metal of ordinary things. I want to make an ordinary thing out of guns. When I went to England I was amazed at what went on, the waste - I'd been taught to re-use everything, the dung from a cow to cool a radiator, a fork to fix a typewriter - India could live for a hundred years on what I saw thrown away.

question: I should go to the house, get breakfast.
answer: The lamp was burning all night in his room. Caravaggio was there with him. This is hot!

question: And did you never see Katharine? You never got back to the Cave?
answer: Yes, I got back there finally to keep my promise. To come back for her. And then of course I couldn't... I couldn't even do that properly.

question: You get to the morning and the poison leaks away, doesn't it? Black nights, fucking black nights, when you want to howl like a dog. I thought I would kill you. You killed my friends, you ruined my hands. But the girl was always here, like some Guardian Angel.
answer: You can't kill me. I died years ago.

question: Stay out of this.
answer: Kip?

question: I looked up to you, Uncle. My brother always said I was a fool. Never trust the British, he said
answer: What are you talking about?

question: What have I been doing all this time? Do you know how many mines I've seen? - more mines than there are soldiers, more - how many mines we've put in the ground ourselves, stuffed in corpses, dropped out of the sky. And now this.
answer: Kip, listen -

question: I said keep out of this! Can you hear? Can you hear what they're celebrating? I listened to you, Uncle. Sitting at your feet - always sitting at somebody's feet - trying to learn. The right way to hold a teacup, otherwise you're out, the pukkah knot in your tie - as if everything can be explained in terms of a cricket bat and an accent.
answer: Kip -

question: Kip! - it's not even my name because you can't say it. Kirpal Singh Bhuller is my name.
answer: Well, then ask him his name!

question: Kip. Kip. It's me. Why? It's another bomb. However big, what's the difference? There've been so many bombs. What about Coventry? What about Dresden? Where were those cities? I don't understand. Let me come in.
answer: Will you come with me?

question: Of course. When?
answer: I mean home. India.

question: Kip... I -
answer: I know - here I am always a brown man, there you would be always a white woman.

question: Is that what you think? Is that what you think I think?
answer: It's what I've learned.

question: I'm thinking about your heart, not your skin. And how to reach it. And that I don't think I can. A bomb has ruined us, just not the bomb I thought would ruin us. I've clung to you. I've clung to you. Kip. Life a raft.
answer: Then come with me.

question: I'll always go back to that church. Look at my painting.
answer: I'll always go back to that church.
